articles.headline: China Escalating Attack on Google
articles.snippet: The Chinese authorities have blocked global versions of the company’s search engines, and Gmail, Calendar and Translate have been affected.
articles.abstract: The Chinese authorities have blocked global versions of the company’s search engines, and Gmail, Calendar and Translate have been affected.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The authorities in China have made Google’s services largely inaccessible in recent days, a move most likely related to the government’s broad efforts to stifle discussion of the 25th anniversary of the crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators in Tiananmen Square on June 3 and 4, 1989.

articles.headline: Democrats in Coal Country Run From E.P.A.
articles.snippet: President Obama’s proposal to cut emissions from coal-fired power plants could become a key election issue in some battleground states.
articles.abstract: President Obama’s proposal to cut emissions from coal-fired power plants could become a key election issue in some battleground states.
articles.lead_paragraph: LEXINGTON, Ky. — It took little time for Alison Lundergan Grimes, the Democrat who is challenging Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the Republican minority leader, in the most high-profile Senate race this year, to distance herself from the Obama administration’s proposal for sharp cuts to emissions from power plants.

articles.headline: Hospital Charges Surge for Common Ailments, Data Shows
articles.snippet: Hospitals charged more for every single one of 98 common ailments in 2012, and the increase for all but seven exceeded the nation’s 2 percent inflation rate for that year, according to a Times analysis.
articles.abstract: Hospitals charged more for every single one of 98 common ailments in 2012, and the increase for all but seven exceeded the nation’s 2 percent inflation rate for that year, according to a Times analysis.
articles.lead_paragraph: Charges for some of the most common inpatient procedures surged at hospitals across the country in 2012 from a year earlier, some at more than four times the national rate of inflation, according to data released by Medicare officials on Monday.
articles.byline: By Julie Creswell, Sheri Fink and Sarah Cohen

articles.headline: Hopes for Impact of Carbon Rules in U.S. Are Modest
articles.snippet: Reductions in coal use will come from relying more on other power sources and making structures more efficient, but both are already happening.
articles.abstract: Reductions in coal use will come from relying more on other power sources and making structures more efficient, but both are already happening.
articles.lead_paragraph: The new carbon pollution rules the Obama administration announced on Monday will help spur the natural gas industry and renewable energy like wind and solar power, but executives and analysts said they did not see the nation’s reliance on coal disappearing anytime soon.
articles.byline: By Clifford Krauss and Diane Cardwell

articles.headline: Do Drug Companies Make Drugs, or Money?
articles.snippet: Short-term financial gain, not a sense of nobility, is behind Valeant Pharmaceuticals’ and William Ackman’s attempt to buy Allergan.
articles.abstract: Short-term financial gain, not a sense of nobility, is behind Valeant Pharmaceuticals’ and William Ackman’s attempt to buy Allergan.
articles.lead_paragraph: “I just want to emphasize that this is an industry where it is composed of really great people, working to do good things for patients, for doctors and actually for society, and when I look at our employees, there is sort of a noble purpose to working in the pharmaceutical industry.”

articles.headline: French Officials Twist U.S. Arms in Bank Inquiry
articles.snippet: The French campaign has focused largely on the concern that BNP, unlike other big banks accused of doing business with Sudan and Iran, might be forced to suspend a core business operation in New York as a result of the guilty plea.
articles.abstract: The French campaign has focused largely on the concern that BNP, unlike other big banks accused of doing business with Sudan and Iran, might be forced to suspend a core business operation in New York as a result of the guilty plea.
articles.lead_paragraph: Facing the prospect of a guilty plea in the United States, the giant French bank BNP Paribas has enlisted the support of a powerful ally: its own government, including top regulators and even the French president.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: Bowe Bergdahl’s Vanishing Before Capture Angered His Unit
articles.snippet: The release of the U.S. soldier has created political problems for both parties amid allegations that he had left his base without permission.
articles.abstract: The release of the U.S. soldier has created political problems for both parties amid allegations that he had left his base without permission.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Sometime after midnight on June 30, 2009, Pfc. Bowe Bergdahl left behind a note in his tent saying he had become disillusioned with the Army, did not support the American mission in Afghanistan and was leaving to start a new life. He slipped off the remote military outpost in Paktika Province on the border with Pakistan and took with him a soft backpack, water, knives, a notebook and writing materials, but left behind his body armor and weapons — startling, given the hostile environment around his outpost.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt, Helene Cooper and Charlie Savage

articles.headline: With Choice at Tiananmen, Student Took Road to Riches
articles.snippet: Xiao Jianhua, the leader of the official student union at Peking University in 1989, sided with the government and found wealth and favor.
articles.abstract: Xiao Jianhua, the leader of the official student union at Peking University in 1989, sided with the government and found wealth and favor.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — A few days after the crackdown on the Tiananmen Square protests 25 years ago, the Chinese government filled the airwaves with a list of the 21 most wanted student leaders accused of stirring up an antigovernment rebellion. At the top of the list was a 20-year-old student at Peking University named Wang Dan, who set up an unofficial student union to mobilize his classmates to demand democracy.
articles.byline: By David Barboza and Michael Forsythe

articles.headline: Tea Party Challenge in Mississippi G.O.P. Primary Goes to the Wire
articles.snippet: Senator Thad Cochran appeared headed for a runoff with a Tea Party-backed challenger in Mississippi, while in Iowa, State Senator Joni Ernst cruised to victory.
articles.abstract: Senator Thad Cochran appeared headed for a runoff with a Tea Party-backed challenger in Mississippi, while in Iowa, State Senator Joni Ernst cruised to victory.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — There was no clear winner early Wednesday in the most hard-fought Republican Senate primary race this year, with the six-term incumbent Thad Cochran of Mississippi and his Tea Party-backed challenger, State Senator Chris McDaniel, running neck and neck after a night of lead changes.

articles.headline: Instagram Goes Beyond Its Gauzy Filters
articles.snippet: The picture-sharing app is rolling out a set of robust new tools to allow users to quickly and easily enhance the images they post.
articles.abstract: The picture-sharing app is rolling out a set of robust new tools to allow users to quickly and easily enhance the images they post.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Instagram, as in Lake Wobegon, everyone is above average.
